what's an operator a few less slides than yesterday an operator is a way of
building an application and driving an application on top of kubernetes behind
kubernetes api s and the idea is that when you have an application like say
database like Postgres or Cassandra or or something like Redis doesn't matter
any complex application will need a lot of domain-specific knowledge that
domain-specific knowledge can be you can use kubernetes and help yourself to
those generic tools that exist in kubernetes like stateful sets CSI deployments ingress to help you try to
solve some of those domain-specific problems but in the end when it comes to really fully automating an application
and by fully automating I mean handling updates from one version to another without waking people up handling
failure recovery if it's needed scale the application up and down depending on some scenarios all of that should be
handled automatically humans should not be involved in this kind of operation because that kind of breaks the promise
that containers gave us containers promised was hey you package it once and runs n everywhere well that's true for
developers but in production there's so much more that needs to be done and so
operators is a pattern you take all this domain-specific knowledge you put it behind kubernetes api so you extend the
kubernetes api so thanks to CR DS and you're able to then have once build it
once and then be used by users again and again like a cloud service just like you
use RDS in on AWS you go and you ask for new database you need another one you
ask for another one the same thing should be true for any kind of open source or closed source software that's
running on top of kubernetes you should be able to just ask for an instance of it and use it you should not have to
understand how to deploy it and manage it so that's the promise that we're trying to fulfill that's where we're
trying to go with this this is very early stages of all of this but there's been a tremendous amount of people that
